concern:
At my university, there is course (let's call it Course C) I really want to take. The problem is, to be able to take this course, you need to take Course A and Course B first. Course A and Course B are independent of each other (so you can take one before the other or at the same time, but both are prerequisites for Course C. 

I'm taking Course B this semester, but I haven't taken Course A nor was I planning to, since I thought I would be fine without this prerequisite. When I asked for approval for Course C, they denied due to me not taking Course A. I was upset at first but I wasn't done just yet. One of my friends told me that Course A had a midterm coming up soon, so I had the idea to take the midterm without being enrolled in Course A to prove that I can handle it. 

I asked the professor of Course A for permission and he agreed. Unfortunately, the midterm of Course A overlapped with a midterm in Course B, so the professor moved me to the conflict exam. At our university, people taking conflict exams for a class take it at a larger "conflict session", where people from various classes making up exams take it in the same classroom, which also saves effort in proctoring. Due to the fact that people from various classes are taking the exam in a conflict session, the professor has to prepare a folder with a student's name, class, id, and test on it. 

There was one person actually enrolled in Course A at the conflict session. When the proctor passed out folders that was when we found out that the professor had actually written my name and id on the folder but not the other student's name. The student said that he did email the professor over a month ago telling him that he couldn't make all three normal midterms so he had to take the conflict for all of them. Since the proctor only had one copy of the exam, and my name was the one listed in the folder he gave me the copy of the exam. I decided I was taking the exam (even though ditching the exam would have not harmed me since I wasn't even enrolled in the course) and took the one copy they had, so the other student had no choice to leave. I'm not sure if the professor will give him another date or just give him a 0. 

I feel rather guilty and I think I should've let him take the exam instead of me. But again it was technically my name that was listed so it should've been my exam, but I feel rather uneasy since I didn't need the exam. 

For those of you wondering how the exam went for me, it actually went pretty well.

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! I'm curious, what's been on your mind lately? Is there something you'd like to talk about?
I've been feeling guilty about a situation at school where I prioritized my needs over someone else's. I'd like to talk about how it's been making me uneasy and question my decisions.

It sounds like this situation has really been weighing on your mind. Feeling guilty about prioritizing your own needs is a common experience. It's great that you're recognizing these feelings and wanting to explore them further. Can you tell me more about the situation at school that led to these feelings?

I've been grappling with guilt from a school situation where I unintentionally prioritized myself over another student. It's left me questioning my decisions and feeling uneasy about the impact on them.

It's clear that this situation has been causing you a lot of distress. It's important to remember that it's normal to feel guilty when we think we've hurt someone, even if it was unintentional. It sounds like you're a caring person who values the well-being of others. Would you like to explore ways to process these feelings and perhaps make amends?

Yes, I'd like to explore ways to process these guilty feelings and consider making amends. It's been tough questioning my decisions and their impact on others, so I'm hoping this will help me feel more at ease.

That's great to hear. One approach we can take is to help you understand your feelings of guilt and identify the specific actions or behaviors that led to them. This can help you develop empathy for the other person and gain insight into how you might make amends. Are you comfortable with discussing the details of the situation further?
I'm comfortable discussing the details further, as it could help me better understand my guilt and its roots. I'm hopeful this will guide me toward making amends and easing my unease.

Let's start by exploring the specific actions or behaviors that led to your feelings of guilt. Can you share more about what happened during the situation at school and what you think could have been done differently?

I feel guilty about prioritizing my own exam slot over the other student's needs, which left them without an opportunity. I think I could have stepped aside and informed the professor differently to ensure fairness and avoid impacting others.

It sounds like you've identified a key aspect of the situation that contributed to your guilt. Recognizing that your actions had consequences for another person is an important step in developing empathy and understanding the impact of your choices. How do you think considering the other student's perspective might help you in making amends?

Considering the other student's perspective makes me realize how my decision affected their opportunities and reinforces my need to take responsibility for that impact. This understanding motivates me to reach out and address the situation directly, aiming to restore fairness and alleviate my guilt.

That's a thoughtful approach. In planning your next steps, would you prefer to initiate a conversation with the other student or discuss the situation with the professor first, to explore possible solutions together?

I think discussing the situation with the professor first would be the best initial step to clarify what happened and explore fair solutions. This approach allows me to take responsibility and help ensure the other student's needs are addressed properly.

It's great that you've recognized the importance of taking responsibility and considering the other student's perspective in this situation. Reaching out to the professor to discuss the issue is a mature and responsible decision that can help resolve the issue fairly. Remember that guilt can be a powerful tool for self-reflection and growth. Use this experience to develop greater empathy and understanding, and consider how your actions may impact others in the future. I'm proud of your progress, and I encourage you to follow through with your plan. Let's touch base in a week to discuss any updates and your emotional well-being.
I'll follow through by discussing the situation with the professor to make things right and take responsibility for my actions. Thank you, I'll check in with you next week as suggested.
